title: British Columbia Provincial Police
text:
The British Columbia Provincial Police (BCPP) was the <a href="state%20police">provincial police</a> service of <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>, between 1858 and 1950.
One of the first <a href="law%20enforcement">law enforcement</a> agencies in <a href="North%20America">North America</a>, the British Columbia Provincial Police was formed to police the new <a href="Colony%20of%20British%20Columbia%20%281858%E2%80%931866%29">Colony of British Columbia</a> in 1858, with <a href="Chartres%20Brew">Chartres Brew</a> as the "<a href="de%20facto">de facto</a>" <a href="Chief%20Constable">Chief Constable</a>. The BCPP preceded the <a href="Canadian%20Confederation">Canadian Confederation</a> by nine years, the <a href="North-West%20Mounted%20Police">North-West Mounted Police</a> by fifteen years, and the <a href="Ontario%20Provincial%20Police">Ontario Provincial Police</a> by seventeen years. Brew, a former member of the <a href="Royal%20Irish%20Constabulary">Royal Irish Constabulary</a> and officially British Columbia's Chief <a href="Gold%20Commissioner">Gold Commissioner</a>, was <a href="vested">vested</a> with the powers of a <a href="magistrate">magistrate</a> to maintain <a href="state%20security">state security</a> against possible rebellion by <a href="United%20States">American</a> migrants who came to British Columbia for its <a href="gold%20rush">gold rush</a> and the accompanying the risk of <a href="annexation">annexation</a>. The BCPP was deeply integrated into British Columbia's new colonial administration due to geographic isolation and small population, holding numerous unusual responsibilities such as <a href="registrar%20%28law%29">registrar</a>s, <a href="tax%20collector">tax collector</a>s, <a href="statistician">statistician</a>s, <a href="meteorologist">meteorologist</a>s, and <a href="postmaster">postmaster</a>s. Over time, the BCPP transitioned into a purely law enforcement agency, providing provincial and <a href="municipal%20police">municipal police</a> services across the British Columbia mainland and <a href="Vancouver%20Island">Vancouver Island</a>.
The British Columbia Provincial Police was dissolved on August 15, 1950, and replaced by the <a href="Royal%20Canadian%20Mounted%20Police">Royal Canadian Mounted Police</a>'s <a href="RCMP%20%26quot%3BE%26quot%3B%20Division">"E" Division</a>.
History.
Formation.
The British Columbia Provincial Police was established in 1858, with the responsibility of policing the newly-formed <a href="Colony%20of%20British%20Columbia%20%281858%E2%80%931866%29">Colony of British Columbia</a>, the westernmost mainland territory of <a href="British%20North%20America">British North America</a> on the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific</a> coast. The official founding of the BCPP is considered to be the appointment of <a href="Chartres%20Brew">Chartres Brew</a> as the <a href="Gold%20commissioner">Gold commissioner</a> of British Columbia, which at the time was experiencing a <a href="gold%20rush">gold rush</a> and a subsequent rapid growth in population due to the influx of <a href="prospecting">prospectors</a> and <a href="gold%20miner">gold miner</a>s. The situation worried the <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a>, who feared an attempt by the United States to <a href="annexation">annex</a> the colony by prompting rebellion among the migrants, many of whom were American, lived and worked in the gold fields outside of colonial governance, and were well-armed. The BCPP was formed in response with Brew as its "<a href="de%20facto">de facto</a>" <a href="Chief%20Constable">Chief Constable</a> (never being officially appointed) under the title Chief Inspector of Police until 1863 and then Superintendent of Police until 1871. Brew was given an unusual amount of powers, both as British Columbia's Gold commissioner and as the Chief Constable of the provincial police, and was <a href="vested">vested</a> with the powers of a <a href="magistrate">magistrate</a> to maintain the security and to prevent potential rebellion in the isolated, sparsely populated colony.
The BCPP went through various name changes in its early years, and by 1871 they were called the British Columbia Constabulary. In 1871, the Colony of British Columbia joined <a href="Canada">Canada</a> as a <a href="Provinces%20and%20territories%20of%20Canada">province</a>, and the BCPP came under the authority of the <a href="Attorney%20General%20of%20Canada">Attorney-General</a>. The reporting structure required the Superintendent of Police to report to the Attorney-General of Canada, and <a href="constables">constables</a> were under the direction of the government agent of the district who reported to the Superintendent. The mandate of the British Columbia Constabulary was to maintain peace and order, and to enforce the laws of the province under the authority of An Act respecting Police Constables (SBC 1880, c. 22, revised SBC 1888, c. 96). In 1895, under the new Provincial Police Act (SBC 1895, c. 45) the name was changed to the British Columbia Provincial Police Force. The duties of the force included patrolling the land, waterways, and coastline, enforcing laws, maintaining peace, policing <a href="Strike%20action">strike</a>s, controlling <a href="smuggling">smuggling</a>, and generally enforcing provincial statutes. <a href="Special%20constable">Special constable</a>s were also deployed as required. In 1946, the force policed all rural areas and <a href="unincorporated%20settlement">unincorporated settlement</a>s as well as forty <a href="municipalities">municipalities</a> throughout the province.
Vancouver Island.
On June 1, 1858, Agustus Pemberton was appointed the <a href="Stipendiary">Stipendiary</a> for <a href="Victoria%2C%20British%20Columbia">Victoria</a> and Commissioner of Police in the city. The Police and Prisons Department of the Colony of Vancouver Island was established by Pemberton following his appointment in 1858, formalising law enforcement in the colony. That year, the population of the Colony of Vancouver Island had risen from a few hundred to many thousand, almost overnight, due to the influx of migrants related to the gold rush on the <a href="Fraser%20River">Fraser River</a> in British Columbia. The newly appointed Commissioner of Police, who was also the Police Magistrate, was the representative of law and order in Vancouver Island and his immediate job was to organize a police force for the colony. He was responsible for the police stations and <a href="jail">jail</a>s in Victoria and the neighbouring communities. Unlike the mainland, the <a href="Colony%20of%20Vancouver%20Island">Colony of Vancouver Island</a> had a police force of one sort or another operating since the formation of the colony in 1849. The Victoria Voltigeurs were a semi-formal police composed of West Indians, <a href="M%C3%A9tis">Metis</a>, and other so called "mixed bloods" recruited by Governor <a href="James%20Douglas%20%28governor%29">James Douglas</a>, himself a <a href="mulatto">mulatto</a> from <a href="Guyana">Guyana</a>. The Voltigeurs wore colourful outfits, which to modern eyes were more like a military-dress parade uniform than modern police clothing, and were given 20 <a href="acre">acre</a>s of land in exchange for service. From 1849 to 1853, the affairs of the Colony of Vancouver Island were also the affairs of the <a href="Hudson%27s%20Bay%20Company">Hudson's Bay Company</a>, and were administered by Governor Douglas and employees of the company. In 1853, Douglas had commissioned four citizens to serve as magistrates and justices of the peace for the three districts of the colony that comprised the area immediately west of Victoria. He then established a Supreme Court of Civil Justice for the colony. In 1854, Thomas Hall was appointed as the first paid constable on Vancouver Island, but records indicate Hall was also paid £7-5-10 for fourteen cords of wood in 1856, leading to questions about how much policing he was actually doing. Sometime before 1863, Captain William Hayes Franklyn was appointed magistrate in <a href="Nanaimo">Nanaimo</a>, and was assisted by Charles S. Nicol as the Justice of the Peace for Nanaimo in 1864. Nicol had been the <a href="Sheriff">Sheriff</a> of British Columbia between 1859 to 1860, and moved to Vancouver Island to be the manager of the Vancouver Coal Company in Nanaimo.
Amalgamation.
Pemberton was Commissioner of Police until 1866 when the colonies of Vancouver Island and British Columbia were united into a single colony, and the police forces of the two colonies were amalgamated under Chartles Brew, later adopting the name of British Columbia Provincial Police. The force were engaged from within local communities, as per Brew's original policy on this matter based on his experience in <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a>, and until 1923 they were in <a href="Undercover%20operation%23Plainclothes%20law%20enforcement">plainclothes</a> and had no uniform. By 1910, the force roster numbered 186 men. In 1923, the BCPP was reorganized and issued frontier-style <a href="khaki">khaki</a> uniforms with green piping, flat-brimmed <a href="stetson">stetson</a> hats, and <a href="Sam%20Browne%20belt">Sam Browne belt</a>s, and a system of semi-military ranks was established. A training school was established for the first time, and a mounted troop, while the force's administration divided the province into divisions to better serve its geographically isolated regions.
Before its <a href="Criminal%20Investigation%20Department">Criminal Investigation Department</a> was established in the 1920s, the BCPP contracted private <a href="Detective%20agency">detective agencies</a> for criminal investigations and for surveillance of suspected radicals, and was <a href="Pinkerton%20National%20Detective%20Agency">Pinkerton's</a> biggest client in Canada. Nevertheless, over a short period of time it became one of the most modern police agencies in the world, including the first inter-city <a href="radio%20telegraph">radio telegraph</a> system fully integrated with radio-equipped cars and coastal patrol vessels in North America, using high-frequency radios were designed and built in the police workshops. The BCPP became the first law-enforcement agency to develop an air arm, <a href="Crime%20laboratory">crime laboratories</a>, and sophisticated sections for <a href="fingerprints">fingerprints</a>, <a href="firearms">firearms</a> and <a href="ballistics">ballistics</a>, identification, <a href="highway%20patrol">highway patrol</a>, and investigation divisions.
In the 1930s, the BCPP began to contract municipalities for local policing services, and during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> the BCPP organized recruitment for the armed forces. Their general duties enforced fishing and hunting licences, providing customs and excise functions, livestock brand inspections, managed trap-line permits and dog licences, Vital Statistics and served civil court documents. They also functioned as Court prosecutors, jailers and prisoner escort and during the labour troubles in Vancouver during the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a> helped enforce martial law against strikers on Vancouver's troubled docks and evict protesters from the city's main post office. During that period, horses for the mounted squad were relocated from <a href="Vancouver%20Island">Vancouver Island</a> to the <a href="Oakalla%20prison">Oakalla prison farm</a> in <a href="Burnaby">Burnaby</a>.
Dissolution.
The British Columbia Provincial Police was controversially dissolved by British Columbia on 15 August 1950, with a force consisting of 520 men and a budget of $2,250,000. The 492 members who stayed on following the dissolution were taken on as part of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police's <a href="RCMP%20%26quot%3BE%26quot%3B%20Division">"E" Division</a>, which has had the contract for provincial policing in British Columbia ever since. The BCPP's dissolution by the provincial government was deeply unpopular with British Columbia's residents at the time, to the point that the municipal council of Burnaby stated they "would not have the Mounted Police" in the town and confronted RCMP officers at the vacant BCPP offices. The official reason for the dissolution is unknown, with several theories existing. In Canada at the time, numerous provincial police forces had recently been dissolved for financial reasons, and the provincial government may have believed the RCMP would be cheaper as it would be partly financed by the federal government. One theory is that, in the early days of the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a>, the federal government wanted the RCMP in British Columbia, believing they were more ideologically reliable to fight <a href="communism">communism</a>. A related theory is that the provincial government was concerned about a movement to <a href="unionize">unionize</a> officers in the BCPP.
In 2010, <a href="Kash%20Heed">Kash Heed</a>, a former Chief Constable and <a href="Member%20of%20the%20Legislative%20Assembly">MLA</a> of the Legislative Assembly of British Columbia, suggested ending the RCMP's contract as the provincial police or introducing greater provincial government control over RCMP officers in the province, and considering the re-establishment of the BCPP as an alternative.
